content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" is a bill that excludes space-related income from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This Act may be cited as the "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003". The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain types of financial amounts. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes income from products or services produced in outer space, services performed in outer space, and certain types of financial amounts. The act also provides exceptions for telecommunications services, services provided by satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space. Additionally, wages received by employees are exempt from this exclusion. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income, including products or services produced in outer space. There are exceptions for telecommunications services, services provided by satellites, and transporting property to or from outer space. Wages received by employees are also exempt from this exclusion. Space-based income is proportionally allocated based on expenses incurred in space production. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal taxes if launched from or manufactured at a facility owned by US persons. The exclusion applies to all federal excises, imposts, duties, and tariffs. Beginning after December 31, 2012, benefits under this act will phase out. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products made in outer space from federal taxes. Starting after December 31, 2012, benefits will phase out gradually. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts space-related income from federal taxes. A new section, "SEC. 45G. SPACE COMPANY INVESTMENT CREDIT," provides a credit for the purchase of qualified space company stock. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. The "Space Company Investment Credit" allows a credit for purchasing qualified stock in a domestic C corporation with specific revenue and business criteria. The "Space Company Investment Credit" provides a credit for purchasing qualified stock in a domestic C corporation with over 70% of gross receipts from space-based business, defined as substantially space-related income. Aggregation rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply, and qualified stock must be acquired from a qualified space company. The "Space Company Investment Credit" allows a credit for buying qualified stock in a domestic C corporation with over 70% of gross receipts from space-based business. The stock must be acquired from a qualified space company and meet certain criteria, including being acquired at its original issue in exchange for money or services provided to the corporation. The "Space Company Investment Credit" requires qualified stock in a C corporation with over 70% of gross receipts from space-based business. The stock must meet active business requirements similar to section 1202(e) and be acquired at its original issue. Rules for stock repurchase by the corporation also apply. The "Space Company Investment Credit" rules apply to qualified stock in a C corporation with over 70% of gross receipts from space-based business. If the issuer ceases to be a qualified space company within 10 years of stock purchase, prior year credits will be recaptured. This section does not apply to stock acquired after December 31, 2011. The amendment to Section 38(b) of the tax code adds a new paragraph for the space company investment credit. Additionally, Section 39(d) is amended to disallow carryback of this credit before January 1, 2004. The tax code amendment disallows carryback of the unused business credit attributable to the space company investment credit before January 1, 2004. The tax code amendment disallows carryback of the unused business credit attributable to the space company investment credit before January 1, 2004. The amendments made by this section apply to costs paid or incurred in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a new section is added for the exclusion of gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. The tax code now excludes gains from selling stock of qualified space corporations, defined as domestic C corporations primarily engaged in producing goods or services in outer space. The tax code excludes gains from selling stock of qualified space corporations, which are C corporations primarily engaged in producing goods or services in outer space. Additionally, at least 90 percent of the expenses of such corporations must be related to the active conduct of their trade or business. The tax code excludes gains from selling stock of qualified space corporations, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2003.
